title: Grade 11 - Introduction to Anthropology, Psychology, and Sociology HSP3U (2013)
subject: Social Science and Humanities

document.title: Grade 11 - Introduction to Anthropology, Psychology, and Sociology HSP3U (2013)

600F3259FC85465BB9BF3C713EF9F07C.description: evaluate the relative influence of primary agents of socialization (e.g., family, peers) and secondary agents of socialization (e.g., media, religion) on the socialization of the individual

B32296EB08E4449C8BB3F548FFB59AD0.description: explain the ways in which social structures (e.g., economy, family, class, race, gender) affect individual and group behaviour

761B08572A5D471280EAF45BF367AD56.description: explain how structural changes take place in social institutions (e.g., family; religious institutions; legal, political, educational, and health systems; the military) in response to diverse influences (e.g., demographic or economic change, introduction of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms, social movements)

CDE21BA2E05F477BB642A8AA915D9702.description: Socialization: use a sociological perspective to explain patterns of socialization.

ABA7C176C5164C719B4037ED5C06D5D9.description: Socialization: use a sociological perspective to explain patterns of socialization.

A5115566B7EA4902B62DAD29F5BB8C32.description: explain, from a sociological perspective, how diverse influences (e.g., culture, religion, economics, media, technology) shape social behaviour (e.g., dating and courtship, social networking, bullying, following trends and fads)

566F38A76F0C4B6CBC27DACBB9ED84F8.description: explain, from a sociological perspective, the relationship between prejudice and individual and systemic discrimination (e.g., on the basis of gender, race, socio-economic status, sexual orientation, ability, religion, age, appearance), and describe their impacts on individuals and society

9B4160969D124EC68C6B8DB768911268.description: explain, from a sociological perspective, how diverse factors (e.g., social norms and expectations, social structures, social distinctions, socio-economic status, geographic location, physical environment, media coverage) influence and shape individual and group behaviour

28C5BCC097564959B2CA9507569EC00F.description: Explaining Social Behaviour: use a sociological perspective to explain how diverse factors influence and shape individual and group social behaviour;

46AD1A5739204CC9B6E9F2CA71D1D429.description: identify and explain the main research methods that are used for conducting sociological research (e.g., surveys, case studies, observations, secondary analysis of statistical results, content analysis, focus groups), and assess critiques of the various methods

CBEC16CE65C943AC8F9425454BE12CFF.description: summarize the key ideas of the major sociological schools of thought (e.g., structural functionalism, symbolic interactionism, conflict theory, feminist perspective), and explain how they can be used to analyse social behaviour

2CF20855507648C7AAE265CDDCCA9AE9.description: explain the significance of contributions of various theorists to the field of sociology (e.g., Emile Durkheim, Karl Marx, Edward Said, Max Weber, Dorothy Smith, Charles Wright-Mills, Reginald Bibby, Gordon Allport, George Dei, Ibn Khaldun)

900D500E54C84382A6BA23972F1C4C26.description: Theories, Perspectives, and Methodologies: demonstrate an understanding of major theories, perspectives, and research methods in sociology;

75886E37CD7F40A59730C2AC8D5DD6BD.description: analyse the procedures of and ethical problems associated with major psychological experiments in socialization (e.g., Zimbardo's Stanford prison experiment, Asch's conformity experiment, Milgram's obedience-to-authority experiment, Elliot's "Blue-Eyed/Brown-Eyed" experiment)

9CC13CDF2B344F389AE8AABEA4C2ECF1.description: assess how diverse personality traits (e.g., introversion, openness to experience, perfectionism) shape human behaviour and interaction in a variety of environments

A8E0F07E20E141F0A77E7B38F6557177.description: identify and describe the role of socialization in the psychological development of the individual (e.g., effects of social isolation on language development, effects of group play experiences on emotional development)

4224A85CEF5A418986F1700720EC2AC6.description: Socialization: use a psychological perspective to analyse patterns of socialization.

9803A473DED04CB894033F19395D1FC7.description: explain how diverse psychological factors (e.g., motivation, perception, attitudes, mental health, temperament) influence individual behaviour

108A81D967F04EC48003BEF0D975B7C8.description:
explain, from a psychological perspective,
ways in which context and the influence of other
individuals can affect people’s emotional and behavioural responses (e.g., at work, within a
family, in sports groups/clubs, in crowds, in urban
versus rural areas, among bystanders)

E16ADB5C26614EDFAAD3D70322E3B1E4.description: explain, from a psychological perspective, how various influences (e.g., heredity, environment, personality, identity, developmental stage, attachment) contribute to an individual's psychological development

5DA41A7CD2204477998E4F21C4AE290D.description: Explaining Human Mental Processes and Behaviour: use a psychological perspective to explain how diverse factors influence and shape human mental processes and behaviour;

AEBF171111784A6991DB4BD102326503.description: compare the major research methods used for conducting psychological research (e.g., experiments, surveys, observations), and assess critiques of the various methods

E6ECEDD1BD414614B1F15A65A41098C2.description: explain the contribution to understanding human behaviour of various psychological approaches (e.g., clinical, experimental, personality, abnormal, and developmental psychology)

B4B3142FD5824B06BC6A762F26A3FA0E.description: summarize the key ideas of major psychological theories (e.g., psychodynamic theory, behaviourism, cognitive theory, humanistic theory, feminist psychology theory), and explain how they can be used to understand human behaviour

A003FA546837460EB8F818AE8548E3BD.description: explain the significance of contributions of influential psychologists (e.g., Erik Erikson, Sigmund Freud, Carl Jung, Abraham Maslow, Ivan Pavlov, Carl Rogers, B. F. Skinner, Thomas Bouchard, Mary Ainsworth, Leta Stetter Hollingworth, Carol Gilligan)

49EBC6316C584095BAF926DC48C6BBEA.description: Theories, Perspectives, and Methodologies: demonstrate an understanding of major theories, perspectives, and research methods in psychology

8C0B0DA17D3E4DEE8977F321CB809981.description: explain ways in which culture is an agent of socialization (e.g., in communicating and upholding such things as kinship rights and obligations, social customs, religious practices)

D128A15B44B1431BAA9B06FDB44B36BC.description: explain how culture produces diverse forms of human behaviour (e.g., explain variations in rites of passage, language, family roles, or political practices from one culture to another)

83C8698DED55455E900B63C7B3758A68.description: Socialization: use a cultural anthropology perspective to explain patterns of human socialization

5C1A3D0927514E0590CA4325E5CABBDD.description: explain how studying cultural systems of different times, places, and groups helps anthropologists understand human behaviour and culture in the present

AE8768BEE9F84A65AFC66BA43D5DB682.description: describe, from an anthropological perspective, the effects that diffusion, assimilation, and multiculturalism have on culture

F6AA9D8F19C2420587BCBBCC5EB70AC4.description: explain, from an anthropological perspective, how various factors (e.g., physical environment, globalization, pandemics) influence and shape human behaviour and culture (e.g., technology, language, social structures, law, politics, religion and ritual, art)

4DDAFD915B7B444AA5467306F21E5CB9.description: Explaining Human Behaviour and Culture: use an anthropological perspective to explain how diverse factors influence and shape human behaviour and culture;

03C67284FD0B479D912798351A636387.description: explain the main research methods used for conducting anthropological research (e.g., participant observation, oral history, semi-structured interview, ethnography, genealogy, archaeological excavation, decolonizing research methods), and assess critiques of the various methods

4D4715B58C574BA997880CD42B058B66.description: explain significant issues in different areas of anthropology (e.g., linguistic anthropology, physical anthropology, cultural anthropology, forensic anthropology, primatology)

7438ECBD48E741ABB7BCDB1AB062DE4E.description: outline the key ideas of the major anthropological schools of thought (e.g., functionalism, structuralism, cultural materialism, feminist anthropology, postmodern or postcolonial anthropology) and explain how they can be used to analyse features of cultural systems

0C6DD8F6877D4961A0AA17E9DA484670.description: explain the significance of contributions of influential anthropologists (e.g., Noam Chomsky, Charles Darwin, Jane Goodall, the Leakeys, Margaret Mead, Edward Sapir, Marvin Harris, Richard Lee, Birut-Galdikas, Sherry Ortner)

7BC67570EF4540CB8E73675F9C5A869A.description: Theories, Perspectives, and Methodologies: demonstrate an understanding of major theories, perspectives, and research methods in anthropology;

FDC68C98F0E748B7813EDD1660388DA6.description: demonstrate an understanding of the general research process by reflecting on and evaluating their own research, inquiry, and communication skills

407270E750B14C93B0793D87534D6B30.description: clearly communicate the results of their inquiries (e.g., write clearly, organize ideas logically, use language conventions properly), and follow APA conventions for acknowledging sources (e.g., generate a reference list in APA style, use in-text author-date citations)

6CDCD7FF957543E586E7060CD50A206D.description: use terms relating to anthropology, psychology, and sociology correctly (e.g., functionalism, structuralism, feminism, culture, socialization, ethnography, survey, archaeology, temperament)

630EC8EA9C14403D95DDC102B22DE3F2.description: use an appropriate format (e.g., oral presentation, poster, written research report, multimedia presentation, seminar, web page) to communicate the results of their research and inquiry effectively for a specific purpose and audience

AD530EACCDFE4034B6ED1F45D44FF95B.description: synthesize findings and formulate conclusions (e.g., determine whether their results support or contradict their hypothesis; weigh and connect information to determine the answer to their research questions; assess the extent to which their results may be affected by factors not included in their research design)

4634DA72C7C740E8964ADFA1A4F0269E.description: demonstrate academic honesty by documenting the sources of all information generated through research

784E6D0936834BCBB3625234CEAE46AA.description: analyse and interpret research information (e.g., compare information gathered from primary and secondary sources; determine whether similar information is found in different sources)

119DF53157024787918148108A0AE87E.description: record and organize information and key ideas using a variety of formats (e.g., notes, graphic organizers, summaries, audio/digital records)

89D6E118AD7A471186F1A6CDF7581793.description: assess various aspects of information gathered from primary and secondary sources (e.g., accuracy, relevance, reliability, inherent values and bias, voice)

06AC2D064ABE49BBB5AFE262BACB7BA8.description: Processing Information: assess, record, analyse, and synthesize information gathered through research and inquiry;

24125AAD320E4EA8BA13BFD2E9C6AB5C.description: based on preliminary research, for each investigation formulate a hypothesis, thesis statement, or research question, and use it to focus their research

80B9894DD6B14F16BE9C6161296F5A92.description: locate and select information relevant to their investigations from a variety of primary sources (e.g., interviews, observations, surveys, questionnaires, original documents in print or other media-film, photographs) and/or secondary sources (e.g., textbooks, literature reviews, research reports, newspaper and magazine articles)

08A0140AB89E42B49498BD9B9329827E.description: create appropriate research plans to investigate their selected topics (e.g., outline purpose and method; identify sources of information; develop research tools such as surveys or questionnaires), ensuring that their plans follow guidelines for ethical research

67AF4CD781494871A57787B523864A6A.description: Investigating: create research plans, and locate and select information relevant to their chosen topics, using appropriate social science research and inquiry methods;

00253401E1184BB5B4404B2478CBCEDE.description: formulate effective questions to guide their research and inquiry

123AEB1DF2D54B58BBD992328C411F02.description: identify key concepts (e.g., through discussion, brainstorming, use of visual organizers) related to their selected topics

7E53AC4D610D43ECA1D35626670BCA32.description: explore a variety of topics related to anthropology, psychology, and sociology (e.g., rites of passage, identity development, effects of social networking) to identify topics for research and inquiry

5456644986F34CDDB88712D85305C646.description: Exploring: explore topics related to anthropology, psychology, and sociology, and formulate questions appropriate to each discipline to guide their research;
